DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Soft Tissue Metastatic Involvement Specify
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a text field to provide an anatomic location where evidence is detected for spread of cancer from a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic cells to soft tissue located in another part of the body.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Soft Tissue Metastatic Involvement
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to evidence of the spread of cancer from a malignant tumor composed of atypical neoplastic cells to an internal organs of the muscle, fat, fibrous tissue, blood vessels, or other supporting tissue of the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Refers to muscle, fat, fibrous tissue, blood vessels, or other supporting tissue of the body.:(MET-uh-STAT-ik) Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from one part of the body to another.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the free text field to specify an anatomic site.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Specify; be specific about something; define clearly.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.

DataElement.origin: ECOG CRF:Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Case Report Form
